action.name: Active Directory - PINGCASTLE, ACL Check
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates the network activity produced by an actor running PINGCASTLE against a domain. PINGCASTLE is a publicly available utility designed to assess the "risk level" of an Active Directory environment. This Action contains network activity when specifically running an ACL check against a domain.

According to Mandiant Intelligence, FIN11 has used PINGCASTLE to perform network reconnaissance in a targeted environment after gaining a foothold. More information on this Activity can be read about in the Mandiant report: [20-00011864](https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/20-00011864).
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an DMZ, Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an Internal/Trusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, COVID-19 Trojan, Download, Variant #1
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates a host attempting to download a malicious trojan dropper delivered via a spearphishing message by the group known as FIN11. The email uses a COVID-19 themed lure in an attempt to deliver a trojan downloader to a victim's computer. Once delivered, attackers can then download additional types of malware including banking Trojans and ransomware. FIN11 is known as one of the most significant financially motivated threat actors due to the extraordinary volumes of messages they send. 

This malware has been identified as being involved in COVID-19 themed phishing campaigns. CISA and NCSC report (Alert AA20-099A) a growing use of COVID-19-related themes by malicious cyber actors.  More information can be found [here.](https://www.us-cert.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-099a)
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Command and Control - FIN11, TINYMET, Reverse Shell over HTTP
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates the initial GET request made by TINYMET when attempting to connect to an attacker's IP address via a HTTP reverse shell over port 443. TINYMET is a publicly available Meterpreter stager which supports multiple meterpreter transports such as TCP, HTTP, and HTTPS. 

According to Mandiant Intelligence, TINYMET has been used by FIN11 is previous campaigns for transferring encoded payloads to a victim's machine. More information on TINYMET can be read about in report: [19-00006048](https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/19-00006048).

action.desc:
This Action demonstrates the malicious file transfer of an RC4-encrypted  FLAWEDAMMYY Remote Access Trojan (RAT). This file is the final stage download and has been seen being used by FIN11.

FLAWEDAMMYY is a modification of the AmmyyAdmin remote access tool that implements additional commands including the ability to run a hidden piped command shell, collect system and user information, launch a MIMIKATZ module for credential stealing, update itself and reboot the host system.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, CLOP, Variant #1
action.desc: This Action demonstrates a host attempting to download a variant of the CLOP ransomware. This variant of the malware has an embedded digital signature to evade security controls. CLOP is a ransomware that encrypts selected file types in an infected system. Upon encryption, the filenames are appended with a ".clop" or ".ciop" extension. The payment instruction is written in a text file dropped in all enumerated folders as either "CLOPREADME.TXT" or "CIOPREADME.TXT."

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, FLAWEDAMMYY, Download, Variant #2
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates the malicious file transfer of an encrypted DLL as a text file. The downloaded file is a text file with a single number on each line. The downloaded payload is a text file with a number per line that is encrypted in XOR with a constant hardcoded value. The decrypted result is an executable file written to the disc and executed.

FLAWEDAMMYY is a modification of the AmmyyAdmin remote access tool that implements additional commands including the ability to run a hidden piped command shell, collect system and user information, launch a MIMIKATZ module for credential stealing, update itself and reboot the host system.

action.desc: This Action demonstrates the malicious file transfer of the FRIENDSPEAK downloader. Since at least 2016, the threat actor group known as FIN11 has distributed the FRIENDSPEAK downloader through phishing campaigns containing malicious documents. FRIENDSPEAK is an HTTP downloader typically seen contained within a MINEDOOR loader. The downloader fetches executable files from a remote C&C server, saves them in the TEMP directory, and launches them.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, FORKBEARD, Download
action.desc: This Action demonstrates the malicious file transfer of the FORKBEARD downloader. In the Fall of 2019, the threat actor group FIN11 deployed FORKBEARD to victim machines infected in phishing campaigns to drop other malicious tools such as BARDWIRE and FlawedAmmyy. FORKBEARD is a dropper that loads and executes its payload in memory. FORKBEARD first decodes shellcode, which then decodes and loads the payload into memory replacing the original binary in the process. Finally, the shellcode invokes the payload's entry point.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, BARBWIRE, Download, Variant #1
action.desc: This Action demonstrates the malicious file transfer of the BARBWIRE backdoor. BARBWIRE was the final stage payload of various campaigns conducted by FIN11 during late 2019 and early 2020. BARBWIRE is a backdoor that connects to a command and control server (C2) using a custom binary protocol. The C2 is obtained from a configuration file. In case no configuration file exists, the malware will use an embedded fallback. The backdoor supports a variety of capabilities including updating the malware, stealing passwords, executing scripts, and self-deletion. The malware also has the ability to render a victim host unbootable by overwriting the beginning of the physical hard drive that contains the operating system with random data.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, NAILGUN, Download, Variant #1
action.desc:
This action demonstrates the download of a variant of NAILGUN.

NAILGUN is an installer/deployment tool that takes a payload given on the command line along with a list of hosts and other settings to deploy malware.  FIN11 has been observed using NAILGUN to deploy CLOP ransomware to hundreds of systems at once, after disabling Windows Defender with SALTLICK.

NAILGUN writes the chosen payload to "%WINDIR%\swaqp.exe", and creates a service named "psxexesvc" pointed towards the payload.  The service is then started and the payload is executed.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, SALTLICK, Download
action.desc:
This action demonstrates the malicious file transfer of of the SALTLICK utility.

SALTLICK disables Windows Defender on a host by modifying registry keys (such as "HKLM\Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows Defender\Real-Time Protection\DisableRealtimeMonitoring").

FIN11 has been observed using SALTLICK to disable Defender prior to using NAILGUN or malicious Group Policy Objects to deploy CLOP ransomware across target environments.

action.name: Command and Control - FIN11, AMADEY, Beacon Check-in
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates an AMADEY beacon checking for new files to download.

AMADEY is a downloader with the ability to execute binaries and DLLs.  It employs detection avoidance techniques, can set up persistence, and uses a beacon every minute to check for new files to download.  It is frequently used by FIN11 to download second-stage payloads.  More information can be found [here](https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/19-00007831).
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Command and Control - FIN11, ANDROMUT, Check-in
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates C2 traffic from ANDROMUT, a dropper used by FIN11.

ANDROMUT receives payloads from the C2 server inside encrypted JSON objects, which are then saved in the %TEMP% directory and executed. ANDROMUT frequently has been seen downloading FLAWEDAMMY after its installation is complete.

More information about ANDROMUT can be found [here](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/ta505-begins-summer-campaigns-new-pet-malware-downloader-andromut-uae-south).

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, MIXLABEL, Download, Variant #4
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates the malicious file transfer of the MIXLABEL backdoor. 

This sample of MIXLABEL is believed to have entered use in summer 2020, containing additional tools (such as certificate pinning) when compared with older versions.  It is tracked by ProofPoint as SDBbot, and is marked as version 3.9

MIXLABEL was the final stage payload of various campaigns conducted by FIN11 during late 2019 and early 2020. The malware dropper, FRIENDSPEAK, was embedded in malicious documents to deploy MIXLABEL with a legitimate PuTTY Secure Fire Transfer Protocol (PSFTP). MIXLABEL is a simple backdoor that communicates using a custom binary protocol and has the ability to create a reverse shell, upload and download files, and list and delete files.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, GOBLINGATE, Download, Variant #1
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates a host attempting to download a variant of GOBLINGATE.

GOBLINGATE is a Linux backdoor that can enumerate system information, download and execute files, install a kernel module, and redirect traffic using a SOCKS5 proxy. The malware can communicate over DNS or TCP. Traffic is encapsulated with base64 encoding, RC4 encryption, and then zlib level 9 compression. This malware masquerades as the service netns and does not have a persistence mechanism.  More information on GOBLINGATE can be found on the [Mandiant Advantage Summary Page](https://advantage.mandiant.com/malware/malware--bddff367-0c7a-59b2-8bd6-0d7ab91b8005). action.name: Command and Control - FIN11, BARBWIRE, Check-in
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates BARBWIRE malware Command and Control (C2) traffic. BARBWIRE, associated with FIN11 also known as TA505, Dudear, or EvilCorp, is a backdoor that connects to a C2 server using a custom binary protocol. It supports a variety of capabilities including updating the malware, stealing passwords, executing scripts, loading additional plugins, establishing RDP connections, and self-deletion. It also has the ability to render a victim host un-bootable by overwriting the Master Boot Record (MBR) with random data.

In this sample, each packet that the malware sends has a 14-byte header:

| CRC32 of the header (4-byte) | "GCRG" (4-byte string) | Unknown (4-byte, may be a packet or connection attempt counter) | Type (2-byte) |

There are three types of packets that follow the header:

Type 1: Contains a variable amount of data.
Type 2: Used for the beacon. Begins with a 4-byte CRC32 checksum of the beacon data. This is followed by 48 bytes of unknown data.
Type 3: Unknown. Begins with a 4-byte CRC32 checksum of the data followed by 34 bytes of data.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - FIN11, POPFLASH, Download, Variant #1
action.desc: This Action demonstrates a host attempting to download a variant of POPFLASH. POPFLASH is a Wow64-aware downloader that loads an embedded plugin DLL to handle all network communications. Command and Control (C2) communications are sent and received to a hard-coded C2 IP address via DNS on UDP port 53 with query type 19 (X25 protocol) using a custom binary protocol. POPFLASH appears capable of downloading and executing additional payloads/plugins and updating its C2 configuration.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Malicious File Transfer - RMS, Download, Variant #1
action.desc: This Action demonstrates a host attempting to download the Remote Manipulator System (RMS) malware. The Remote Manipulator System (RMS) is a legitimate remote administration tool (RAT) developed by a Russian company named TektonIT. Mandiant investigations found that FIN6, and FIN11 financially motivated groups, used the tool to remotely control compromised systems. Attackers deployed the tool using a 7-Zip self-extracting executable (SFX) alongside a malicious VBScript and a DLL.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.desc:
This Action demonstrates a host attempting to download WOOLLYBEAR. WOOLLYBEAR is an HTTP backdoor that can execute commands. It connects to a fixed Command and Control (C2) host and parses the HTTP response for a set of delimiters that contain a command to execute within.

Mandiant Threat Intelligence has identified WOOLLYBEAR as being used by FIN11.
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

action.name: Command and Control - FIN11, POPFLASH, C2 Traffic via DNS, Variant #1
action.desc:
This Action demonstrates an host infected with POPFLASH communicating with the C2 infrastructure via DNS on UDP port 53. POPFLASH is a Wow64 aware downloader that load an embedded plugin DLL to handle all network communications. C2 communications are sent and received to a hard-coded C2 IP address via DNS on UDP port 53 with query type 19 using a custom binary protocol.

Mandiant Intelligence has attributed the use of POPFLASH to the threat group FIN11. More information can be read in Mandiant Advantage Report [20-00011864](https://advantage.mandiant.com/reports/20-00011864).
action.notes: Mandiant Security Validation recommends selecting a source Actor in an Internal/Trusted security zone and a destination Actor in an External/Untrusted zone.

integrations.name: Splunk ES Integration

search_replacements.replacement: \1 eval filtered_signature=mvfilter(signature != "fe_ml_heuristic") | search filtered_signature IN (%{signature}) AND occurred="%{orig_occurred}" |

integrations.query:
search (index=*_sec OR index=*_dns OR index=*_proxy OR index=*_fw OR index=*_nix) AND NOT (sourcetype=verodin:syslog OR sourcetype=verodin_events) earliest=-30m  %ACTOR_IPS% AND _indextime>=%LAST_INDEX%
| eval src_ip=coalesce(src_ip,c_ip,src,sip,id_orig_h,"Unknown") 
| eval dest_ip=coalesce('alert.dst.ip',dest_ip,dest,dst,dip,id_resp_h,"Unknown") 
| eval src_port=coalesce(src_translated_port,src_port,sport,"Unknown") 
| eval dest_port=coalesce('alert.dst.port',dest_port,dport,"Unknown") 
| eval sig_id=coalesce(sig_id,severity_id,signature_id,'alert.id',id,"Unknown") 
| eval filehashes=coalesce(sha256sum,sha1sum,md5sum,'event_values.processEvent/md5',"Unknown")
| eval name=coalesce(name,threat_name,event,signature,action,event_description,s_action,message,"Unknown") 
| eval host=coalesce(sensor_name,dhost,host,sourcetype,"Unknown") 
| eval hx_event_time=strptime(start_time, "%b %d %Y %H:%M:%S %Z") | eval _time=coalesce(hx_event_time, _time)| fields src_ip,dest_ip,sig_id,src_port,dest_port,name,event_time,host,filehashes,index,product,action,vendor_action,log_subtype
integrations.correlation_query: search earliest=-12h _indextime>=%START_TIME% AND _indextime<=%END_TIME% AND %ACTOR_IPS% AND `notable` | rex field=_raw "'occurred': '(?<orig_occurred>.*?)'" | eval _raw=substr(_raw, 1, 1024)
integrations.dns_action_query:
search (index=*_sec OR index=*_proxy OR index=*_dns) earliest=-30m %DOMAINS% AND _indextime>=%LAST_INDEX% 
| eval url=coalesce(url, query, "Unknown") 
| eval src_ip=coalesce(src_ip,c_ip,src,"Unknown") 
| eval dest_ip=coalesce(dest_ip,dest,dest_host,"Unknown") 
| eval src_port=coalesce(src_port,"Unknown") 
| eval dest_port=coalesce(dest_port,"Unknown") 
| eval sig_id=coalesce(sig_id,severity_id,"Unknown") 
| eval name=coalesce(name,action,event,signature_id,signature,message_type,record_type,"Unknown") 
| fields name,event_time,host,url,sig_id,src_ip,dest_ip,src_port,dest_port
integrations.email_action_query:
search index=gis_email sourcetype=pps_messagelog earliest=-1h  (NOT (filter.quarantine.folder = "ADQUEUE")) AND envelope.from=%SENDERS% AND envelope.rcpts=%RECIPIENTS% AND _indextime>=%LAST_INDEX%
| rename  msg.normalizedHeader.subject{} AS subject, envelope.from AS email_sender, envelope.rcpts AS email_recipient, filter.modules.av.virusNames{} as signature_name, filter.startTime as event_time, msgParts{}.urls{}.url as urls, filter.quarantine.folder as quarantine_folder, filter.quarantine.rule as quarantine_rule
| eval name= final_action . ": " .  if (signature_name == "" OR isnull(signature_name), "No Signature", "Signature: " . signature_name ) . " - " . if (quarantine_folder == "" OR isnull(quarantine_folder), " Not Quarantined", "Quarantine info: " . quarantine_rule . " (".  quarantine_folder . ")")
| fields subject,email_sender,email_recipient,final_action, signature_name,event_time,host, urls, quarantine_folder, quarantine_rule, name
integrations.last_query:
search (index=*_sec OR index=*_dns OR index=*_proxy OR index=*_fw OR index=*_nix) AND NOT (sourcetype=verodin:syslog OR sourcetype=verodin_events) earliest=-30m  (160.33.90.23 OR 3.212.102.156) AND _indextime>=1675190707
| eval src_ip=coalesce(src_ip,c_ip,src,sip,id_orig_h,"Unknown") 
| eval dest_ip=coalesce('alert.dst.ip',dest_ip,dest,dst,dip,id_resp_h,"Unknown") 
| eval src_port=coalesce(src_translated_port,src_port,sport,"Unknown") 
| eval dest_port=coalesce('alert.dst.port',dest_port,dport,"Unknown") 
| eval sig_id=coalesce(sig_id,severity_id,signature_id,'alert.id',id,"Unknown") 
| eval filehashes=coalesce(sha256sum,sha1sum,md5sum,'event_values.processEvent/md5',"Unknown")
| eval name=coalesce(name,threat_name,event,signature,action,event_description,s_action,message,"Unknown") 
| eval host=coalesce(sensor_name,dhost,host,sourcetype,"Unknown") 
| eval hx_event_time=strptime(start_time, "%b %d %Y %H:%M:%S %Z") | eval _time=coalesce(hx_event_time, _time)| fields src_ip,dest_ip,sig_id,src_port,dest_port,name,event_time,host,filehashes,index,product,action,vendor_action,log_subtype

integrations.host_cli_action_query:
search (index=*_sec OR index=*_dns OR index=*_proxy) earliest=-30m (%HOST_CLI_ACTOR_HOSTNAMES% OR %HOST_CLI_ACTOR_IPS%) AND _indextime>=%LAST_INDEX% 
| rex field=ComputerName "^(?<hostname>.+?)\." 
| eval hx_event_time=strptime(start_time, "%b %d %Y %H:%M:%S %Z") | eval _time=coalesce(detected_timestamp, hx_event_time, _time)
| eval name=coalesce(ThreatName,EventMessage, description, event, name, event_description, message, "Unknown") 
| eval src_ip=coalesce(src_ip, dest_ip, src, IP_Address, hostname, "Unknown") 
| eval dest_ip=src_ip 
| eval sig_id=coalesce(EventCode, rule, signature_id, "Unknown") 
| eval user=coalesce(user, username, "Unknown") 
| eval filehashes=coalesce(sha256sum,sha1sum,md5sum,'event_values.processEvent/md5',"Unknown")
| eval host=coalesce(fqdn, hostname, Computer, MachineName, src_host, dhost, host) 
| fields src_ip, dest_ip, sig_id, name, host, user , filehashes
| dedup host, name, sig_id
